title: JSON-Powered Portfolio
subtitle: This Very Website
intro: A minimal, fast personal portfolio website where all content is sourced from local JSON files, emphasizing a content-as-data architecture.
content:
This project is a practical implementation of a 'No CMS' philosophy. By storing all content—from project descriptions to essays—in structured JSON files within the GitHub repository, the entire site becomes version-controlled, transparent, and easily editable with a simple text editor. The front-end, built with Next.js and Tailwind CSS, is a static-first application that fetches and renders this data at build time, ensuring maximum performance and security.

Key features include a client-side search function written in plain JavaScript, dynamic page generation for categories and individual posts, and a clean, responsive design. The workflow is streamlined: edit a JSON file, commit, and deploy. It's an exercise in simplicity and developer-centric content management.

title: Data Visualization Kit
subtitle: A Component Library for React
intro: A custom-built component library designed to simplify the creation of interactive and aesthetically pleasing charts and graphs in React applications.
content:
Frustrated with the complexity and heavy dependencies of existing charting libraries, I developed a lightweight Data Visualization Kit. Built with React and styled-components, it provides a set of reusable components for common chart types like bar, line, and pie charts. The library is designed with a focus on customization and performance, using CSS variables for easy theming and minimizing re-renders through memoization.

The project involved a deep dive into SVG manipulation, animation with Framer Motion, and building an accessible and developer-friendly API. It's currently used in several internal dashboards and has significantly reduced the time required to build data-rich interfaces.
